intro: Passerina granatensis, commonly known as the Granada pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the Iberian Peninsula. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its showy, early spring blooms. The plant produces cup-shaped flowers that are typically pink or white, with five petals and numerous stamens. It thrives in rocky or gravelly soils and is often found in open woodlands and mountainous regions. Passerina granatensis is a short-lived perennial, with a life cycle closely tied to the seasonal availability of moisture.
